Introduction ðŸ˜›

Welcome to this Probability Study Guide! This guide provides a refresher of fundamental probability concepts and detailed solutions to specific problems. It is structured to first review key ideas (with examples) and then apply them to solve problems step-by-step.

How to use this guide:

  • Begin with the Probability Refresher section to recall important definitions, formulas, and distributions. Work through the examples to reinforce your understanding.
  • Proceed to the Problem Solutions section. For each problem, try to understand the Derivation-based solution (step-by-step reasoning) and then see the Shortcut-based solution (using known formulas or tricks like MGFs).
  • Use the guide actively: pause at examples, attempt to solve them, and compare your approach with the given solution. Happy studying! ðŸŽ‰

Basic Probability Rules

Probability provides a quantitative description of the chances or likelihood of events. Some fundamental rules and properties include:

  • Range of Probability: For any event AAA, 0â‰¤P(A)â‰¤10 \le P(A) \le 10â‰¤P(A)â‰¤1. The probability of the entire sample space Î©\OmegaÎ© is 1, and the probability of the impossible event âˆ…\emptysetâˆ… is 0.
  • Complement Rule: P(Ac)=1âˆ’P(A)P(A^c) = 1 - P(A)P(Ac)=1âˆ’P(A), where AcA^cAc is the complement of AAA. (The probability that AAA does not occur.)
  • Addition Rule: For events AAA and BBB, P(AâˆªB)=P(A)+P(B)âˆ’P(Aâˆ©B)P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A \cap B)P(AâˆªB)=P(A)+P(B)âˆ’P(Aâˆ©B). If AAA and BBB are mutually exclusive (cannot occur together), then P(Aâˆ©B)=0P(A \cap B)=0P(Aâˆ©B)=0 and P(AâˆªB)=P(A)+P(B)P(A \cup B) = P(A) + P(B)P(AâˆªB)=P(A)+P(B).
  • Conditional Probability: P(Aâˆ£B)=P(Aâˆ©B)P(B)P(A \mid B) = \frac{P(A \cap B)}{P(B)}P(Aâˆ£B)=P(B)P(Aâˆ©B)â€‹, provided P(B)>0P(B) > 0P(B)>0. This is the probability of AAA given that BBB has occurred.
  • Multiplication Rule: Rearranging the above, P(Aâˆ©B)=P(Aâˆ£B)â€‰P(B)=P(Bâˆ£A)â€‰P(A)P(A \cap B) = P(A \mid B)\,P(B) = P(B \mid A)\,P(A)P(Aâˆ©B)=P(Aâˆ£B)P(B)=P(Bâˆ£A)P(A). For independent events (no influence on each other), P(Aâˆ©B)=P(A)â€‰P(B)P(A \cap B) = P(A)\,P(B)P(Aâˆ©B)=P(A)P(B).
  • Bayesâ€™ Theorem: P(Bâˆ£A)=P(Aâˆ£B)â€‰P(B)P(A)P(B \mid A) = \frac{P(A \mid B)\,P(B)}{P(A)}P(Bâˆ£A)=P(A)P(Aâˆ£B)P(B)â€‹. This allows updating probabilities when new information (AAA) is obtained about prior event BBB.

Example: Let P(A)=0.4P(A)=0.4P(A)=0.4, P(B)=0.5P(B)=0.5P(B)=0.5, and P(Aâˆ©B)=0.1P(A \cap B)=0.1P(Aâˆ©B)=0.1. Then P(AâˆªB)=0.4+0.5âˆ’0.1=0.8P(A \cup B) = 0.4+0.5-0.1 = 0.8P(AâˆªB)=0.4+0.5âˆ’0.1=0.8. The conditional probability P(Aâˆ£B)=P(Aâˆ©B)/P(B)=0.1/0.5=0.2P(A \mid B) = P(A \cap B)/P(B) = 0.1/0.5 = 0.2P(Aâˆ£B)=P(Aâˆ©B)/P(B)=0.1/0.5=0.2. Here P(Aâˆ©B)P(A \cap B)P(Aâˆ©B) is not equal to 0.4Ã—0.5=0.20.4 \times 0.5 = 0.20.4Ã—0.5=0.2, so AAA and BBB are not independent in this example (since 0.1â‰ 0.20.1 \neq 0.20.1î€ =0.2). If they were independent, we would expect P(Aâˆ©B)=P(A)P(B)P(A \cap B) = P(A)P(B)P(Aâˆ©B)=P(A)P(B).

Uniform, Exponential, and Beta Distributions

Understanding common probability distributions is essential. Here we review three fundamental continuous distributions:

Uniform Distribution: A continuous random variable XXX is Uniform on an interval [a,b][a, b][a,b], denoted Xâˆ¼U(a,b)X \sim U(a,b)Xâˆ¼U(a,b), if its probability density function (pdf) is constant on [a,b][a,b][a,b].

  • PDF: fX(x)=1bâˆ’af_X(x) = \frac{1}{b-a}fXâ€‹(x)=bâˆ’a1â€‹ for aâ‰¤xâ‰¤ba \le x \le baâ‰¤xâ‰¤b (and 0 outside this interval). All intervals of equal length inside [a,b][a,b][a,b] are equally likely.
  • CDF: FX(x)=P(Xâ‰¤x)=xâˆ’aâ€‰bâˆ’aâ€‰F_X(x) = P(X \le x) = \frac{x-a}{\,b-a\,}FXâ€‹(x)=P(Xâ‰¤x)=bâˆ’axâˆ’aâ€‹ for aâ‰¤xâ‰¤ba \le x \le baâ‰¤xâ‰¤b. (For x<ax < ax<a, FX(x)=0F_X(x)=0FXâ€‹(x)=0; for xâ‰¥bx \ge bxâ‰¥b, FX(x)=1F_X(x)=1FXâ€‹(x)=1.)
  • Mean and Variance: E[X]=a+b2E[X] = \frac{a+b}{2}E[X]=2a+bâ€‹, Var(X)=(bâˆ’a)212\mathrm{Var}(X) = \frac{(b-a)^2}{12}Var(X)=12(bâˆ’a)2â€‹.
  • Example: If Xâˆ¼U(1,3)X \sim U(1,3)Xâˆ¼U(1,3), then fX(x)=1/2f_X(x)=1/2fXâ€‹(x)=1/2 on [1,3][1,3][1,3]. The probability P(X<2)P(X < 2)P(X<2) is 2âˆ’13âˆ’1=0.5\frac{2-1}{3-1} = 0.53âˆ’12âˆ’1â€‹=0.5. Likewise P(X>2.5)=3âˆ’2.52=0.25P(X>2.5) = \frac{3-2.5}{2} = 0.25P(X>2.5)=23âˆ’2.5â€‹=0.25.

Exponential Distribution: The Exponential distribution models waiting times between independent events that occur at a constant average rate. If XXX is Exponential with rate Î»>0\lambda>0Î»>0, denoted Xâˆ¼Exp(Î»)X \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)Xâˆ¼Exp(Î»), then:

  • PDF: fX(x)=Î»eâˆ’Î»xf_X(x) = \lambda e^{-\lambda x}fXâ€‹(x)=Î»eâˆ’Î»x for xâ‰¥0x \ge 0xâ‰¥0 (and 0 for x<0x < 0x<0). It is a decreasing function, meaning smaller values of XXX are more likely.
  • CDF: FX(x)=1âˆ’eâˆ’Î»xF_X(x) = 1 - e^{-\lambda x}FXâ€‹(x)=1âˆ’eâˆ’Î»x for xâ‰¥0x \ge 0xâ‰¥0. (At x=0x=0x=0, FX(0)=0F_X(0)=0FXâ€‹(0)=0; as xâ†’âˆžx \to \inftyxâ†’âˆž, FX(x)â†’1F_X(x) \to 1FXâ€‹(x)â†’1.)
  • Mean and Variance: E[X]=1Î»E[X] = \frac{1}{\lambda}E[X]=Î»1â€‹, Var(X)=1Î»2\mathrm{Var}(X) = \frac{1}{\lambda^2}Var(X)=Î»21â€‹.
  • Memoryless Property: P(X>s+tâˆ£X>s)=P(X>t)\displaystyle P(X > s+t \mid X > s) = P(X > t)P(X>s+tâˆ£X>s)=P(X>t). In words, given that one has waited sss time units already, the conditional distribution of the additional waiting time is the same as the original distribution. (The exponential is the only continuous distribution with this property.)
  • Example: If Xâˆ¼Exp(1)X \sim \text{Exp}(1)Xâˆ¼Exp(1) (unit rate), then P(X>2)=eâˆ’1â‹…2=eâˆ’2â‰ˆ0.1353P(X > 2) = e^{-1\cdot 2} = e^{-2} \approx 0.1353P(X>2)=eâˆ’1â‹…2=eâˆ’2â‰ˆ0.1353. The probability P(Xâ‰¤3)P(X \le 3)P(Xâ‰¤3) is 1âˆ’eâˆ’3â‰ˆ0.95021 - e^{-3} \approx 0.95021âˆ’eâˆ’3â‰ˆ0.9502. Beta Distribution: The Beta distribution is a family of distributions on the interval [0,1][0,1][0,1] with two shape parameters, often used to model probabilities or proportions. We denote Xâˆ¼Beta(Î±,Î²)X \sim \text{Beta}(\alpha,\beta)Xâˆ¼Beta(Î±,Î²) for Î±,Î²>0\alpha, \beta > 0Î±,Î²>0.

  • PDF: fX(x)=1B(Î±,Î²)xÎ±âˆ’1(1âˆ’x)Î²âˆ’1f_X(x) = \frac{1}{B(\alpha,\beta)} x^{\alpha - 1}(1-x)^{\beta - 1}fXâ€‹(x)=B(Î±,Î²)1â€‹xÎ±âˆ’1(1âˆ’x)Î²âˆ’1 for 0â‰¤xâ‰¤10 \le x \le 10â‰¤xâ‰¤1.   • CDF: There is no simple closed-form CDF except in terms of the incomplete beta function. However, probabilities can be computed via the regularized incomplete beta.
  • Mean and Variance: E[X]=Î±Î±+Î²E[X] = \frac{\alpha}{\alpha + \beta}E[X]=Î±+Î²Î±â€‹, and Var(X)=Î±Î²(Î±+Î²)2(Î±+Î²+1)\mathrm{Var}(X) = \frac{\alpha \beta}{(\alpha + \beta)^2 (\alpha + \beta + 1)}Var(X)=(Î±+Î²)2(Î±+Î²+1)Î±Î²â€‹.
  • Special cases: As noted, Beta(1,1)\text{Beta}(1,1)Beta(1,1) is just U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1) (uniform on [0,1]). If Î±\alphaÎ± and Î²\betaÎ² are integers, the Beta distribution can be seen as the distribution of an order statistic of uniforms (more on this below). For instance, if X1,â€¦,XnX_1,\dots,X_nX1â€‹,â€¦,Xnâ€‹ are i.i.d. U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1), then the $k$th smallest observation has distribution Beta(k,â€…â€Šnâˆ’k+1)\text{Beta}(k,\;n-k+1)Beta(k,nâˆ’k+1).
  • Example: Xâˆ¼Beta(2,2)X \sim \text{Beta}(2,2)Xâˆ¼Beta(2,2) has pdf fX(x)=6x(1âˆ’x)f_X(x) = 6x(1-x)fXâ€‹(x)=6x(1âˆ’x) for 0<x<10<x<10<x<1, which is symmetric around 0.5. Joint Distributions and Independence

When dealing with multiple random variables, we describe their behavior using joint distributions:

  • For continuous random variables XXX and YYY, the joint PDF fX,Y(x,y)f_{X,Y}(x,y)fX,Yâ€‹(x,y) satisfies P((X,Y)âˆˆA)=âˆ¬AfX,Y(x,y)â€‰dxâ€‰dyP((X,Y) \in A) = \iint_A f_{X,Y}(x,y)\,dx\,dyP((X,Y)âˆˆA)=âˆ¬Aâ€‹fX,Yâ€‹(x,y)dxdy for any region AAA in the plane. The joint PDF must integrate to 1 over the entire support: âˆ¬âˆ’âˆžâˆžfX,Y(x,y)â€‰dxâ€‰dy=1\iint_{-\infty}^{\infty} f_{X,Y}(x,y)\,dx\,dy = 1âˆ¬âˆ’âˆžâˆžâ€‹fX,Yâ€‹(x,y)dxdy=1.
  • Marginal distributions: We can recover the distribution of XXX alone (the marginal fX(x)f_X(x)fXâ€‹(x)) by integrating out YYY: fX(x)=âˆ«âˆ’âˆžâˆžfX,Y(x,y)â€‰dyf_X(x) = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} f_{X,Y}(x,y)\,dyfXâ€‹(x)=âˆ«âˆ’âˆžâˆžâ€‹fX,Yâ€‹(x,y)dy. Similarly fY(y)=âˆ«fX,Y(x,y)â€‰dxf_Y(y) = \int f_{X,Y}(x,y)\,dxfYâ€‹(y)=âˆ«fX,Yâ€‹(x,y)dx.
  • Independence: XXX and YYY are independent if and only if their joint PDF factors into the product of the marginals: fX,Y(x,y)=fX(x)â€‰fY(y)f_{X,Y}(x,y) = f_X(x)\, f_Y(y)fX,Yâ€‹(x,y)=fXâ€‹(x)fYâ€‹(y) for all (x,y)(x,y)(x,y) in the support. Intuitively, knowing the value of one gives no information about the distribution of the other. Equivalently (for continuous variables), FX,Y(x,y)=FX(x)FY(y)F_{X,Y}(x,y) = F_X(x) F_Y(y)FX,Yâ€‹(x,y)=FXâ€‹(x)FYâ€‹(y). If this factorization does not hold, XXX and YYY are dependent. Dependence often manifests via a restricted support region or a non-factorizable density.

Example (Independent variables): If XXX and YYY are independent U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1) random variables, then fX,Y(x,y)=1â‹…1=1f_{X,Y}(x,y) = 1 \cdot 1 = 1fX,Yâ€‹(x,y)=1â‹…1=1 on the unit square 0â‰¤xâ‰¤1,â€‰0â‰¤yâ‰¤10\le x\le1,\,0\le y\le10â‰¤xâ‰¤1,0â‰¤yâ‰¤1. The marginals are each uniform(0,1). Because the support is a rectangle and the density factors, XXX and YYY are independent.

Example (Dependent variables): Suppose (X,Y)(X,Y)(X,Y) is uniformly distributed over a triangular region: S={(x,y):0â‰¤xâ‰¤1,â€…â€Š1âˆ’xâ‰¤yâ‰¤1}S = \{(x,y): 0 \le x \le 1,\; 1-x \le y \le 1\}S={(x,y):0â‰¤xâ‰¤1,1âˆ’xâ‰¤yâ‰¤1}. This means XXX and YYY can only take values in SSS (for instance, if x=0.2x=0.2x=0.2, then yyy must be between 0.80.80.8 and 111). The joint density can be written as fX,Y(x,y)=kf_{X,Y}(x,y) = kfX,Yâ€‹(x,y)=k on SSS (and 0 outside), where kkk is a normalization constant. In this case, the support is not a simple rectangle (itâ€™s a triangle in the unit square), so XXX and YYY are not independent. (Weâ€™ll explore this scenario in Problem 2.)

Expectation and Variance

For a random variable XXX:

  • The expectation (or mean) E[X]E[X]E[X] is the long-run average value of XXX. For a continuous XXX, E[X]=âˆ«âˆ’âˆžâˆžxâ€‰fX(x)â€‰dxE[X] = \int_{-\infty}^{\infty} x\,f_X(x)\,dxE[X]=âˆ«âˆ’âˆžâˆžâ€‹xfXâ€‹(x)dx, provided the integral converges. For a discrete XXX, E[X]=âˆ‘xxâ€‰P(X=x)E[X] = \sum_x x \, P(X=x)E[X]=âˆ‘xâ€‹xP(X=x).
  • Linearity of expectation: E[aX+bY+c]=aâ€‰E[X]+bâ€‰E[Y]+cE[aX + bY + c] = a\,E[X] + b\,E[Y] + cE[aX+bY+c]=aE[X]+bE[Y]+c for any constants a,b,ca,b,ca,b,c. (Importantly, this holds regardless of whether XXX and YYY are independent.)
  • The variance Var(X)=E[(Xâˆ’E[X])2]=E[X2]âˆ’(E[X])2\mathrm{Var}(X) = E[(X - E[X])^2] = E[X^2] - (E[X])^2Var(X)=E[(Xâˆ’E[X])2]=E[X2]âˆ’(E[X])2 measures the spread or dispersion of XXX around its mean. A higher variance means more variability.
  • For a constant aaa and random variable XXX, Var(aX)=a2â€‰Var(X)\mathrm{Var}(aX) = a^2\,\mathrm{Var}(X)Var(aX)=a2Var(X). If XXX and YYY are independent, Var(X+Y)=Var(X)+Var(Y)\mathrm{Var}(X+Y) = \mathrm{Var}(X) + \mathrm{Var}(Y)Var(X+Y)=Var(X)+Var(Y) (variances add for independent sums, since thereâ€™s no covariance term).
  • Standard deviation ÏƒX=Var(X)\sigma_X = \sqrt{\mathrm{Var}(X)}ÏƒXâ€‹=Var(X)â€‹ is the square root of variance, in the same units as XXX.

Examples:

  • If Xâˆ¼U(0,1)X \sim U(0,1)Xâˆ¼U(0,1), we have E[X]=0.5E[X] = 0.5E[X]=0.5 and Var(X)=1/12â‰ˆ0.0833\mathrm{Var}(X) = 1/12 \approx 0.0833Var(X)=1/12â‰ˆ0.0833.
  • If Xâˆ¼Exp(Î»)X \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)Xâˆ¼Exp(Î»), then E[X]=1/Î»E[X] = 1/\lambdaE[X]=1/Î» and Var(X)=1/Î»2\mathrm{Var}(X) = 1/\lambda^2Var(X)=1/Î»2. For instance, for Exp(1)\text{Exp}(1)Exp(1), E[X]=1E[X]=1E[X]=1 and Var(X)=1\mathrm{Var}(X)=1Var(X)=1.
  • Suppose XXX takes values {0,1,2}\{0,1,2\}{0,1,2} with P(X=0)=0.2P(X=0)=0.2P(X=0)=0.2, P(X=1)=0.5P(X=1)=0.5P(X=1)=0.5, P(X=2)=0.3P(X=2)=0.3P(X=2)=0.3. Then E[X]=0(0.2)+1(0.5)+2(0.3)=1.1E[X] = 0(0.2)+1(0.5)+2(0.3) = 1.1E[X]=0(0.2)+1(0.5)+2(0.3)=1.1. To find Var(X)\mathrm{Var}(X)Var(X), first compute E[X2]=02(0.2)+12(0.5)+22(0.3)=0+0.5+1.2=1.7E[X^2] = 0^2(0.2)+1^2(0.5)+2^2(0.3) = 0 + 0.5 + 1.2 = 1.7E[X2]=02(0.2)+12(0.5)+22(0.3)=0+0.5+1.2=1.7. Thus Var(X)=1.7âˆ’(1.1)2=1.7âˆ’1.21=0.49\mathrm{Var}(X) = 1.7 - (1.1)^2 = 1.7 - 1.21 = 0.49Var(X)=1.7âˆ’(1.1)2=1.7âˆ’1.21=0.49.

Moment Generating Functions (MGFs)

The moment generating function of a random variable XXX is defined as MX(t)=E[etX]M_X(t) = E[e^{tX}]MXâ€‹(t)=E[etX], for values of ttt in some neighborhood of 0 where this expectation exists. The MGF is a very useful tool because:

  • It generates moments: the $n$th moment E[Xn]E[X^n]E[Xn] can be obtained by differentiating MX(t)M_X(t)MXâ€‹(t) nnn times and evaluating at t=0t=0t=0:

    E[Xn]=MX(n)(0)=dndtnMX(t)âˆ£t=0.E[X^n] = M_X^{(n)}(0) = \left.\frac{d^n}{dt^n} M_X(t)\right|_{t=0}. E[Xn]=MX(n)â€‹(0)=dtndnâ€‹MXâ€‹(t)â€‹t=0â€‹.

    For example, E[X]=MXâ€²(0)E[X] = M_X'(0)E[X]=MXâ€²â€‹(0) and Var(X)=MXâ€²â€²(0)âˆ’[MXâ€²(0)]2\mathrm{Var}(X) = M_X''(0) - [M_X'(0)]^2Var(X)=MXâ€²â€²â€‹(0)âˆ’[MXâ€²â€‹(0)]2.
  • MGFs (if they exist in an open interval containing 000) uniquely determine the distribution. This means if two random variables have the same MGF, they have the same distribution.
  • Sum of independent variables: If XXX and YYY are independent, MX+Y(t)=E[et(X+Y)]=E[etXetY]=E[etX]â€‰E[etY]=MX(t)â€‰MY(t)M_{X+Y}(t) = E[e^{t(X+Y)}] = E[e^{tX} e^{tY}] = E[e^{tX}]\,E[e^{tY}] = M_X(t)\,M_Y(t)MX+Yâ€‹(t)=E[et(X+Y)]=E[etXetY]=E[etX]E[etY]=MXâ€‹(t)MYâ€‹(t). So the MGF of a sum is the product of MGFs. This property makes it easier to find distributions of sums (e.g. the sum of independent exponentials has an MGF that factors nicely, revealing it is a Gamma distribution).

Examples:

  • For Xâˆ¼Exp(Î»)X \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)Xâˆ¼Exp(Î»), MX(t)=E[etX]=âˆ«0âˆžetxÎ»eâˆ’Î»xâ€‰dx=Î»âˆ«0âˆžeâˆ’(Î»âˆ’t)xâ€‰dxM_X(t) = E[e^{tX}] = \int_0^\infty e^{tx} \lambda e^{-\lambda x}\,dx = \lambda \int_0^\infty e^{-(\lambda - t)x}\,dxMXâ€‹(t)=E[etX]=âˆ«0âˆžâ€‹etxÎ»eâˆ’Î»xdx=Î»âˆ«0âˆžâ€‹eâˆ’(Î»âˆ’t)xdx (which converges for t<Î»t < \lambdat<Î»). Evaluating the integral gives MX(t)=Î»Î»âˆ’tM_X(t) = \frac{\lambda}{\lambda - t}MXâ€‹(t)=Î»âˆ’tÎ»â€‹ for t<Î»t < \lambdat<Î».   • If X1,X2X_1, X_2X1â€‹,X2â€‹ are independent and both âˆ¼Exp(Î»)\sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)âˆ¼Exp(Î»), then MX1+X2(t)=MX1(t)â€‰MX2(t)=(Î»Î»âˆ’t)(Î»Î»âˆ’t)=(Î»Î»âˆ’t)2M_{X_1+X_2}(t) = M_{X_1}(t)\,M_{X_2}(t) = \left(\frac{\lambda}{\lambda - t}\right)\left(\frac{\lambda}{\lambda - t}\right) = \left(\frac{\lambda}{\lambda - t}\right)^2MX1â€‹+X2â€‹â€‹(t)=MX1â€‹â€‹(t)MX2â€‹â€‹(t)=(Î»âˆ’tÎ»â€‹)(Î»âˆ’tÎ»â€‹)=(Î»âˆ’tÎ»â€‹)2. In general, the sum of nnn independent Exp(Î»\lambdaÎ») is Gamma(n,Î»)\text{Gamma}(n,\lambda)Gamma(n,Î»).

  • The Central Limit Theorem (CLT) can also be illustrated via MGFs: if X1,â€¦,XnX_1,\ldots,X_nX1â€‹,â€¦,Xnâ€‹ are i.i.d. with finite mean Î¼\muÎ¼ and variance Ïƒ2\sigma^2Ïƒ2, the MGF of the standardized sum âˆ‘i=1nXiâˆ’nÎ¼Ïƒn\frac{\sum_{i=1}^n X_i - n\mu}{\sigma\sqrt{n}}Ïƒnâ€‹âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹Xiâ€‹âˆ’nÎ¼â€‹ tends to et2/2e^{t^2/2}et2/2 as nâ†’âˆžn\to\inftynâ†’âˆž, which is the MGF of a standard Normal N(0,1)N(0,1)N(0,1). (This is one way to see that the sum tends toward a normal distribution.)

Order Statistics

Given a sample of nnn i.i.d. random variables X1,X2,â€¦,XnX_1, X_2, \dots, X_nX1â€‹,X2â€‹,â€¦,Xnâ€‹, the order statistics are the sample values sorted from smallest to largest. Denote them as Y(1)â‰¤Y(2)â‰¤â‹¯â‰¤Y(n)Y_{(1)} \le Y_{(2)} \le \cdots \le Y_{(n)}Y(1)â€‹â‰¤Y(2)â€‹â‰¤â‹¯â‰¤Y(n)â€‹, where Y(1)Y_{(1)}Y(1)â€‹ is the minimum and Y(n)Y_{(n)}Y(n)â€‹ is the maximum. In general, Y(k)Y_{(k)}Y(k)â€‹ is called the $k$th order statistic (the $k$th smallest value). Properties include:

  • Distribution of min and max: Itâ€™s straightforward to derive these. Let X(1)=minâ¡{X1,â€¦,Xn}X_{(1)} = \min\{X_1,\dots,X_n\}X(1)â€‹=min{X1â€‹,â€¦,Xnâ€‹} and X(n)=maxâ¡{X1,â€¦,Xn}X_{(n)} = \max\{X_1,\dots,X_n\}X(n)â€‹=max{X1â€‹,â€¦,Xnâ€‹}.

    • CDF of the minimum: FY(1)(y)=P(minâ¡Xiâ‰¤y)=1âˆ’P(allÂ Xi>y)=1âˆ’[1âˆ’FX(y)]nF_{Y_{(1)}}(y) = P(\min X_i \le y) = 1 - P(\text{all }X_i > y) = 1 - [1 - F_X(y)]^nFY(1)â€‹â€‹(y)=P(minXiâ€‹â‰¤y)=1âˆ’P(allÂ Xiâ€‹>y)=1âˆ’[1âˆ’FXâ€‹(y)]n. For example, if Xiâˆ¼U(0,1)X_i \sim U(0,1)Xiâ€‹âˆ¼U(0,1), then P(Y(1)>0.2)=[P(Xi>0.2)]n=(0.8)nP(Y_{(1)} > 0.2) = [P(X_i > 0.2)]^n = (0.8)^nP(Y(1)â€‹>0.2)=[P(Xiâ€‹>0.2)]n=(0.8)n.
    • CDF of the maximum: FY(n)(y)=P(maxâ¡Xiâ‰¤y)=P(allÂ Xiâ‰¤y)=[FX(y)]nF_{Y_{(n)}}(y) = P(\max X_i \le y) = P(\text{all }X_i \le y) = [F_X(y)]^nFY(n)â€‹â€‹(y)=P(maxXiâ€‹â‰¤y)=P(allÂ Xiâ€‹â‰¤y)=[FXâ€‹(y)]n. For i.i.d. U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1), P(Y(n)â‰¤0.5)=(0.5)nP(Y_{(n)} \le 0.5) = (0.5)^nP(Y(n)â€‹â‰¤0.5)=(0.5)n.
    • Differentiating yields PDFs: fY(1)(y)=n[1âˆ’FX(y)]â€‰nâˆ’1fX(y)f_{Y_{(1)}}(y) = n[1-F_X(y)]^{\,n-1} f_X(y)fY(1)â€‹â€‹(y)=n[1âˆ’FXâ€‹(y)]nâˆ’1fXâ€‹(y) and fY(n)(y)=n[FX(y)]â€‰nâˆ’1fX(y)f_{Y_{(n)}}(y) = n[F_X(y)]^{\,n-1} f_X(y)fY(n)â€‹â€‹(y)=n[FXâ€‹(y)]nâˆ’1fXâ€‹(y). Intuitively, for the max, this is like: one of the XiX_iXiâ€‹ hits approximately yyy (with density fX(y)f_X(y)fXâ€‹(y)) and the other nâˆ’1n-1nâˆ’1 values are all below yyy (each contributing a factor FX(y)F_X(y)FXâ€‹(y)). Symmetrically for the min.

  • Distribution of $k$th order statistic (1<k<n1 < k < n1<k<n): In general, Y(k)Y_{(k)}Y(k)â€‹ has PDF:

    fY(k)(y)=n!(kâˆ’1)!(nâˆ’k)!â€…â€Š[FX(y)]â€‰kâˆ’1â€…â€Š[1âˆ’FX(y)]â€‰nâˆ’kâ€…â€ŠfX(y),forÂ yÂ inÂ support.\displaystyle f_{Y_{(k)}}(y) = \frac{n!}{(k-1)!(n-k)!}\;[F_X(y)]^{\,k-1}\;[1 - F_X(y)]^{\,n-k}\;f_X(y), \quad \text{for } y \text{ in support.} fY(k)â€‹â€‹(y)=(kâˆ’1)!(nâˆ’k)!n!â€‹[FXâ€‹(y)]kâˆ’1[1âˆ’FXâ€‹(y)]nâˆ’kfXâ€‹(y),forÂ yÂ inÂ support.

    This formula comes from the fact that out of nnn samples, (kâˆ’1)(k-1)(kâˆ’1) must fall below yyy, one is at yyy, and (nâˆ’k)(n-k)(nâˆ’k) above yyy, and there are n!(kâˆ’1)!(nâˆ’k)!\frac{n!}{(k-1)!(n-k)!}(kâˆ’1)!(nâˆ’k)!n!â€‹ ways to choose which observations those are.

  • Order stats and Beta distribution (for uniform samples): If Xiâˆ¼U(0,1)X_i \sim U(0,1)Xiâ€‹âˆ¼U(0,1), then FX(x)=xF_X(x) = xFXâ€‹(x)=x. Plugging into the formula gives fY(k)(y)=n!(kâˆ’1)!(nâˆ’k)!yâ€‰kâˆ’1(1âˆ’y)â€‰nâˆ’kf_{Y_{(k)}}(y) = \frac{n!}{(k-1)!(n-k)!} y^{\,k-1}(1-y)^{\,n-k}fY(k)â€‹â€‹(y)=(kâˆ’1)!(nâˆ’k)!n!â€‹ykâˆ’1(1âˆ’y)nâˆ’k for 0<y<10<y<10<y<1. This is exactly the Beta(k,â€…â€Šnâˆ’k+1)\text{Beta}(k,\; n-k+1)Beta(k,nâˆ’k+1) density. So Y(k)âˆ¼Beta(k,â€…â€Šnâˆ’k+1)Y_{(k)} \sim \text{Beta}(k,\;n-k+1)Y(k)â€‹âˆ¼Beta(k,nâˆ’k+1) when the sample is uniform(0,1). For example, the median of 5 samples from U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1) (Y(3)Y_{(3)}Y(3)â€‹ for n=5n=5n=5) has distribution Beta(3,3)\text{Beta}(3,3)Beta(3,3), which is symmetric on [0,1].

  • Examples:

    • If we draw n=2n=2n=2 samples from U(0,1)U(0,1)U(0,1), the max Y(2)Y_{(2)}Y(2)â€‹ has CDF P(Y(2)â‰¤y)=y2P(Y_{(2)} \le y) = y^2P(Y(2)â€‹â‰¤y)=y2, so fY(2)(y)=2yf_{Y_{(2)}}(y) = 2yfY(2)â€‹â€‹(y)=2y (for 0<y<10<y<10<y<1). Indeed Y(2)âˆ¼Beta(2,1)Y_{(2)} \sim \text{Beta}(2,1)Y(2)â€‹âˆ¼Beta(2,1). The min Y(1)Y_{(1)}Y(1)â€‹ has P(Y(1)>y)=(1âˆ’y)2P(Y_{(1)} > y) = (1-y)^2P(Y(1)â€‹>y)=(1âˆ’y)2, so P(Y(1)â‰¤y)=1âˆ’(1âˆ’y)2P(Y_{(1)} \le y) = 1-(1-y)^2P(Y(1)â€‹â‰¤y)=1âˆ’(1âˆ’y)2, and fY(1)(y)=2(1âˆ’y)f_{Y_{(1)}}(y) = 2(1-y)fY(1)â€‹â€‹(y)=2(1âˆ’y), which is Beta(1,2)\text{Beta}(1,2)Beta(1,2).
    • If Xiâˆ¼Exp(Î»)X_i \sim \text{Exp}(\lambda)Xiâ€‹âˆ¼Exp(Î»), the minimum Y(1)=minâ¡iXiY_{(1)} = \min_i X_iY(1)â€‹=miniâ€‹Xiâ€‹ has an exponential distribution with rate nÎ»n\lambdanÎ» (faster rate because having nnn opportunities for a small value makes the minimum likely very small). Specifically, P(Y(1)>y)=P(allÂ Xi>y)=eâˆ’nÎ»yP(Y_{(1)} > y) = P(\text{all }X_i > y) = e^{-n\lambda y}P(Y(1)â€‹>y)=P(allÂ Xiâ€‹>y)=eâˆ’nÎ»y, so Y(1)âˆ¼Exp(nÎ»)Y_{(1)} \sim \text{Exp}(n\lambda)Y(1)â€‹âˆ¼Exp(nÎ»). The maximum of exponentials doesnâ€™t have such a simple form, but its distribution can be derived from the general order statistic formula if needed.

Problem Solutions âœ…

Below are detailed solutions to each problem. For each part, we present a Derivation-based solution (step-by-step reasoning using fundamental definitions) and a Shortcut-based solution (leveraging known results or formulas for a quicker solve). Mathematical rigor is maintained in both approaches, but the shortcut highlights how recognizing patterns can save time.

Problem 1 ðŸŽ²

Given:

  • Xâˆ¼U(1,3)X \sim U(1,3)Xâˆ¼U(1,3) and Yâˆ¼U(2,5)Y \sim U(2,5)Yâˆ¼U(2,5) are independent continuous random variables.
  • Define W=Xâ€‰YW = X \, YW=XY. (So WWW is the product of XXX and YYY.)

  1. The distribution of Z=âˆ’lnâ¡â€‰â£(Xâˆ’12)Z = -\ln\!\Big(\frac{X - 1}{2}\Big)Z=âˆ’ln(2Xâˆ’1â€‹).

  3. (Bonus) The conditional CDF FWâˆ£Y(wâˆ£y)F_{W\mid Y}(w \mid y)FWâˆ£Yâ€‹(wâˆ£y) (the CDF of WWW given Y=yY=yY=y, in general form).

Part 1: Distribution of Z=âˆ’logâ¡â€‰â£(Xâˆ’12)Z = -\log\!\big(\frac{X-1}{2}\big)Z=âˆ’log(2Xâˆ’1â€‹)

  • Derivation-based solution: This problem involves a transformation of the random variable XXX. First, note that Xâˆ’12\frac{X-1}{2}2Xâˆ’1â€‹ is simply a linear transformation of XXX. Since Xâˆ¼U(1,3)X \sim U(1,3)Xâˆ¼U(1,3), the range of XXX is [1,3][1,3][1,3]. Thus the range of U:=Xâˆ’12U := \frac{X-1}{2}U:=2Xâˆ’1â€‹ is [0,1][0,1][0,1] (because when X=1X=1X=1, (Xâˆ’1)/2=0(X-1)/2 = 0(Xâˆ’1)/2=0, and when X=3X=3X=3, (Xâˆ’1)/2=1(X-1)/2 = 1(Xâˆ’1)/2=1).     P(Uâ‰¤u)=Pâ€‰â£(Xâˆ’12â‰¤u)=P(Xâ‰¤2u+1).P(U \le u) = P\!\Big(\frac{X-1}{2} \le u\Big) = P(X \le 2u + 1). P(Uâ‰¤u)=P(2Xâˆ’1â€‹â‰¤u)=P(Xâ‰¤2u+1).

    Since XXX is uniform on [1,3][1,3][1,3], P(Xâ‰¤2u+1)=(2u+1)âˆ’13âˆ’1=2u2=uP(X \le 2u+1) = \frac{(2u+1) - 1}{3-1} = \frac{2u}{2} = uP(Xâ‰¤2u+1)=3âˆ’1(2u+1)âˆ’1â€‹=22uâ€‹=u. (This result could also be obtained by noting the linear transformation of a uniform yields a uniform: if Xâˆ¼U(a,b)X \sim U(a,b)Xâˆ¼U(a,b) then Xâˆ’aâ€‰bâˆ’aâ€‰âˆ¼U(0,1)\frac{X-a}{\,b-a\,} \sim U(0,1)bâˆ’aXâˆ’aâ€‹âˆ¼U(0,1).)

    Now Z=âˆ’lnâ¡(U)Z = -\ln(U)Z=âˆ’ln(U) where Uâˆ¼U(0,1)U \sim U(0,1)Uâˆ¼U(0,1). Letâ€™s derive this formally by finding the CDF of ZZZ: for zâ‰¥0z \ge 0zâ‰¥0,

    FZ(z)=P(Zâ‰¤z)=P(âˆ’lnâ¡Uâ‰¤z)=P(lnâ¡Uâ‰¥âˆ’z)(multiplyingÂ byÂ -1Â flipsÂ inequality)=P(Uâ‰¥eâˆ’z)=1âˆ’P(U<eâˆ’z)=1âˆ’FU(eâˆ’z).\begin{aligned} \begin{aligned} F_Z(z) &= P(Z \le z) = P(-\ln U \le z) \ &= P(\ln U \ge -z) \quad\text{(multiplying by -1 flips inequality)} \ &= P(U \ge e^{-z}) \ &= 1 - P(U < e^{-z}) \ &= 1 - F_U(e^{-z}). \end{aligned} ]
    FZâ€‹(z)â€‹=P(Zâ‰¤z)=P(âˆ’lnUâ‰¤z)=P(lnUâ‰¥âˆ’z)(multiplyingÂ byÂ -1Â flipsÂ inequality)=P(Uâ‰¥eâˆ’z)=1âˆ’P(U<eâˆ’z)=1âˆ’FUâ€‹(eâˆ’z).â€‹

    For 0<eâˆ’zâ‰¤10 < e^{-z} \le 10<eâˆ’zâ‰¤1, we have FU(eâˆ’z)=eâˆ’zF_U(e^{-z}) = e^{-z}FUâ€‹(eâˆ’z)=eâˆ’z (since UUU is uniform on [0,1][0,1][0,1]). Thus

    FZ(z)=1âˆ’eâˆ’z,zâ‰¥0.F_Z(z) = 1 - e^{-z}, \quad z \ge 0. FZâ€‹(z)=1âˆ’eâˆ’z,zâ‰¥0.

    This is exactly the CDF of an Exp(1)\text{Exp}(1)Exp(1) distribution. (For z<0z < 0z<0, FZ(z)=0F_Z(z)=0FZâ€‹(z)=0 since Zâ‰¥0Z \ge 0Zâ‰¥0 always.) Differentiating, the PDF of ZZZ is fZ(z)=eâˆ’zf_Z(z) = e^{-z}fZâ€‹(z)=eâˆ’z for zâ‰¥0z \ge 0zâ‰¥0. Therefore, ZZZ is Exponential with rate 111.

  • Shortcut-based solution: Recognize that Xâˆ’12âˆ¼U(0,1)\frac{X-1}{2} \sim U(0,1)2Xâˆ’1â€‹âˆ¼U(0,1). Thereâ€™s a known fact: if Uâˆ¼Uniform(0,1)U \sim \text{Uniform}(0,1)Uâˆ¼Uniform(0,1), then âˆ’lnâ¡(U)âˆ¼Exponential(1)-\ln(U) \sim \text{Exponential}(1)âˆ’ln(U)âˆ¼Exponential(1). This result comes from the fundamental connection between the uniform and exponential distributions (often used in simulation: to generate an Exp(Î»\lambdaÎ») one can take âˆ’1Î»lnâ¡U-\frac{1}{\lambda}\ln Uâˆ’Î»1â€‹lnU). Using this directly, we conclude Z=âˆ’lnâ¡â€‰â£(Xâˆ’12)âˆ¼Exp(1)Z = -\ln\!\big(\frac{X-1}{2}\big) \sim \text{Exp}(1)Z=âˆ’ln(2Xâˆ’1â€‹)âˆ¼Exp(1). Part 2: P(Wâ‰¤8âˆ£Y=4)P(W \le 8 \mid Y = 4)P(Wâ‰¤8âˆ£Y=4)

  • Derivation-based solution: Here we are asked for a conditional probability given Y=4Y=4Y=4. When conditioning on Y=4Y=4Y=4, we treat Y=4Y=4Y=4 as known information. Because XXX and YYY are independent, the conditional distribution of XXX given Y=4Y=4Y=4 is just the distribution of XXX itself (independence implies XXX is unaffected by knowing YYY). So XXX remains U(1,3)U(1,3)U(1,3). Now W=Xâ‹…YW = X \cdot YW=Xâ‹…Y. If Y=4Y=4Y=4, then W=4XW = 4XW=4X. Thus:

    P(Wâ‰¤8âˆ£Y=4)=P(4Xâ‰¤8âˆ£Y=4)=P(Xâ‰¤2âˆ£Y=4).P(W \le 8 \mid Y=4) = P(4X \le 8 \mid Y=4) = P(X \le 2 \mid Y=4). P(Wâ‰¤8âˆ£Y=4)=P(4Xâ‰¤8âˆ£Y=4)=P(Xâ‰¤2âˆ£Y=4).

    (We divided both sides of the inequality by 4; since 4 is positive this preserves the inequality direction.) Now P(Xâ‰¤2âˆ£Y=4)=P(Xâ‰¤2)P(X \le 2 \mid Y=4) = P(X \le 2)P(Xâ‰¤2âˆ£Y=4)=P(Xâ‰¤2) because XXX is independent of YYY. Since Xâˆ¼U(1,3)X \sim U(1,3)Xâˆ¼U(1,3), we can compute this probability easily:

    P(Xâ‰¤2)=2âˆ’1â€‰3âˆ’1â€‰=12=0.5.P(X \le 2) = \frac{2 - 1}{\,3 - 1\,} = \frac{1}{2} = 0.5. P(Xâ‰¤2)=3âˆ’12âˆ’1â€‹=21â€‹=0.5.

    Thus, the answer is 0.5\displaystyle 0.50.5.

  • Shortcut-based solution: Reasoning directly, when Y=4Y=4Y=4, the random variable WWW becomes 4X4X4X. The condition Wâ‰¤8W \le 8Wâ‰¤8 then simplifies to Xâ‰¤2X \le 2Xâ‰¤2. We know XXX is uniform on [1,3][1,3][1,3], so the proportion of the interval [1,3][1,3][1,3] where Xâ‰¤2X \le 2Xâ‰¤2 is exactly half of it (from 1 to 2 is half of the length from 1 to 3). Therefore, without doing any integration, we can see P(Xâ‰¤2)=0.5P(X \le 2) = 0.5P(Xâ‰¤2)=0.5. The conditional probability P(Wâ‰¤8âˆ£Y=4)P(W \le 8 \mid Y=4)P(Wâ‰¤8âˆ£Y=4) is the same 0.50.50.5.

Part 3: Conditional CDF FWâˆ£Y(wâˆ£y)F_{W\mid Y}(w \mid y)FWâˆ£Yâ€‹(wâˆ£y) (Bonus)

  • Derivation-based solution: We want the distribution of WWW given an arbitrary Y=yY=yY=y. Treat yyy as a constant in the analysis. Given Y=yY=yY=y, we have W=Xâ‹…yW = X \cdot yW=Xâ‹…y. This is a linear scaling of XXX by the factor yyy. Since Xâˆ¼U(1,3)X \sim U(1,3)Xâˆ¼U(1,3) (independent of YYY), conditional on Y=yY=yY=y, XXX is still uniform (1,3)(1,3)(1,3). Therefore:

    • The minimum possible value of WWW (given Y=yY=yY=y) is when XXX takes its minimum 1, yielding Wminâ¡=1â‹…y=yW_{\min} = 1 \cdot y = yWminâ€‹=1â‹…y=y.
    • The maximum possible value of WWW is when X=3X=3X=3, giving Wmaxâ¡=3yW_{\max} = 3yWmaxâ€‹=3y.

    Because XXX given Y=yY=yY=y is uniform on [1,3][1,3][1,3], the transformed variable W=yâ‹…XW = y \cdot XW=yâ‹…X will be uniform on [y,â€‰3y][y,\,3y][y,3y]. (For a fixed yyy, this is just a stretch of the interval by factor yyy.) We can formally derive the conditional CDF by: for www in the range [y,3y][y,3y][y,3y],

    FWâˆ£Y(wâˆ£y)=P(Wâ‰¤wâˆ£Y=y)=P(yXâ‰¤wâˆ£Y=y).F_{W\mid Y}(w \mid y) = P(W \le w \mid Y=y) = P(y X \le w \mid Y=y). FWâˆ£Yâ€‹(wâˆ£y)=P(Wâ‰¤wâˆ£Y=y)=P(yXâ‰¤wâˆ£Y=y).

    Since y>0y>0y>0 (in fact yâˆˆ[2,5]y\in[2,5]yâˆˆ[2,5] given YYY's support), divide by yyy:

Part 3: MY1(t)M_{Y_1}(t)MY1â€‹â€‹(t) for Y1=minâ¡{X1,â€¦,Xn}Y_1 = \min\{X_1,\ldots,X_n\}Y1â€‹=min{X1â€‹,â€¦,Xnâ€‹} (Bonus)

    Method 2: Beta distribution of order statistic:

  • Shortcut-based solution: The reasoning about â€œat least 4 samples above 0.75â€ can be done more directly: for Y4Y_4Y4â€‹ to exceed 0.75, at most 3 samples can be â‰¤0.75\le 0.75â‰¤0.75 (equivalently, at least (nâˆ’3)(n-3)(nâˆ’3) samples are >0.75>0.75>0.75). Part 3: Joint density fYi,Yj,Yk(yi,yj,yk)f_{Y_i,Y_j,Y_k}(y_i, y_j, y_k)fYiâ€‹,Yjâ€‹,Ykâ€‹â€‹(yiâ€‹,yjâ€‹,ykâ€‹) (Bonus)

  • Derivation-based solution: The joint PDF of multiple order statistics can be derived from the symmetric joint density of the original sample. In general, if 1â‰¤i<j<kâ‰¤n1 \le i < j < k \le n1â‰¤i<j<kâ‰¤n, the joint density for Y(i),Y(j),Y(k)Y_{(i)}, Y_{(j)}, Y_{(k)}Y(i)â€‹,Y(j)â€‹,Y(k)â€‹ (the $i$th, $j$th, and $k$th order stats) is:

    fY(i),â€‰Y(j),â€‰Y(k)(yi,yj,yk)=n!(iâˆ’1)!â€‰(jâˆ’iâˆ’1)!â€‰(kâˆ’jâˆ’1)!â€‰(nâˆ’k)!Ã—[fX(yi)]â€‰[fX(yj)]â€‰[fX(yk)]Ã—[FX(yi)]â€‰iâˆ’1â€…â€Š[FX(yj)âˆ’FX(yi)]â€‰â€‰jâˆ’iâˆ’1Ã—[FX(yk)âˆ’FX(yj)]â€‰â€‰kâˆ’jâˆ’1â€…â€Š[1âˆ’FX(yk)]â€‰nâˆ’k,\begin{aligned} f_{Y_{(i)},\,Y_{(j)},\,Y_{(k)}}(y_i, y_j, y_k) &= \frac{n!}{(i-1)!\, (j-i-1)!\, (k-j-1)!\, (n-k)!} \\ &\quad \times [f_X(y_i)]\,[f_X(y_j)]\,[f_X(y_k)] \\ &\quad \times [F_X(y_i)]^{\,i-1}\;[F_X(y_j) - F_X(y_i)]^{\,\,j-i-1} \\ &\quad \times [F_X(y_k) - F_X(y_j)]^{\,\,k-j-1}\;[1 - F_X(y_k)]^{\,n-k}, \end{aligned}fY(i)â€‹,Y(j)â€‹,Y(k)â€‹â€‹(yiâ€‹,yjâ€‹,ykâ€‹)â€‹=(iâˆ’1)!(jâˆ’iâˆ’1)!(kâˆ’jâˆ’1)!(nâˆ’k)!n!â€‹Ã—[fXâ€‹(yiâ€‹)][fXâ€‹(yjâ€‹)][fXâ€‹(ykâ€‹)]Ã—[FXâ€‹(yiâ€‹)]iâˆ’1[FXâ€‹(yjâ€‹)âˆ’FXâ€‹(yiâ€‹)]jâˆ’iâˆ’1Ã—[FXâ€‹(ykâ€‹)âˆ’FXâ€‹(yjâ€‹)]kâˆ’jâˆ’1[1âˆ’FXâ€‹(ykâ€‹)]nâˆ’k,â€‹

    valid for 0â‰¤yiâ‰¤yjâ‰¤ykâ‰¤10 \le y_i \le y_j \le y_k \le 10â‰¤yiâ€‹â‰¤yjâ€‹â‰¤ykâ€‹â‰¤1.     Now, for our specific case XXX is uniform(0,1). So fX(x)=1f_X(x) = 1fXâ€‹(x)=1 on [0,1][0,1][0,1], and FX(x)=xF_X(x) = xFXâ€‹(x)=x on [0,1][0,1][0,1]. Substituting these in simplifies the formula greatly (all fX(yâˆ—)f_X(y_*)fXâ€‹(yâˆ—â€‹) terms become 1, and FX(y)=yF_X(y) = yFXâ€‹(y)=y):

    fY(i),â€‰Y(j),â€‰Y(k)(yi,yj,yk)=n!(iâˆ’1)!â€‰(jâˆ’iâˆ’1)!â€‰(kâˆ’jâˆ’1)!â€‰(nâˆ’k)!Ã—[yi]â€‰iâˆ’1â€…â€Š[yjâˆ’yi]â€‰â€‰jâˆ’iâˆ’1â€…â€Š[ykâˆ’yj]â€‰â€‰kâˆ’jâˆ’1â€…â€Š[1âˆ’yk]â€‰nâˆ’k,\begin{aligned} f_{Y_{(i)},\,Y_{(j)},\,Y_{(k)}}(y_i, y_j, y_k) &= \frac{n!}{(i-1)!\,(j-i-1)!\,(k-j-1)!\,(n-k)!} \\ &\quad \times [y_i]^{\,i-1}\;[y_j - y_i]^{\,\,j-i-1}\;[y_k - y_j]^{\,\,k-j-1}\;[1 - y_k]^{\,n-k}, \end{aligned}fY(i)â€‹,Y(j)â€‹,Y(k)â€‹â€‹(yiâ€‹,yjâ€‹,ykâ€‹)â€‹=(iâˆ’1)!(jâˆ’iâˆ’1)!(kâˆ’jâˆ’1)!(nâˆ’k)!n!â€‹Ã—[yiâ€‹]iâˆ’1[yjâ€‹âˆ’yiâ€‹]jâˆ’iâˆ’1[ykâ€‹âˆ’yjâ€‹]kâˆ’jâˆ’1[1âˆ’ykâ€‹]nâˆ’k,â€‹

    for 0â‰¤yiâ‰¤yjâ‰¤ykâ‰¤10 \le y_i \le y_j \le y_k \le 10â‰¤yiâ€‹â‰¤yjâ€‹â‰¤ykâ€‹â‰¤1. This is the joint PDF of the $i$th, $j$th, and $k$th order statistics of a sample of size nnn from Uniform(0,1)\text{Uniform}(0,1)Uniform(0,1).

    Itâ€™s worth noting that this is essentially a Dirichlet distribution form (the joint distribution of multiple order stats from uniform is related to sorted uniform spacings). If we were to integrate this over appropriate ranges we could derive marginal distributions or other properties. But as the final answer, the above formula is the most explicit form of the joint density.

  • Shortcut-based solution: One could recall that the vector of order statistics (Y(1),â€¦,Y(n))(Y_{(1)},\dots,Y_{(n)})(Y(1)â€‹,â€¦,Y(n)â€‹) for uniform samples has a Dirichlet distribution for the spacings: specifically, the gaps Y(1)âˆ’0Y_{(1)} - 0Y(1)â€‹âˆ’0, Y(2)âˆ’Y(1)Y_{(2)}-Y_{(1)}Y(2)â€‹âˆ’Y(1)â€‹, ..., Y(n)âˆ’Y(nâˆ’1)Y_{(n)}-Y_{(n-1)}Y(n)â€‹âˆ’Y(nâˆ’1)â€‹, 1âˆ’Y(n)1 - Y_{(n)}1âˆ’Y(n)â€‹ are independent Beta(1,n)\text{Beta}(1, n)Beta(1,n) etc. But it's easier to just remember the general formula for joint order stat density (as given above). Plugging fX(x)=1f_X(x)=1fXâ€‹(x)=1 and FX(x)=xF_X(x)=xFXâ€‹(x)=x yields the simplified result quickly.
